Literature Review: The intricate relationship between food and inequality has been a focal point of sociological research, revealing how the global food system is deeply intertwined with structures of power that perpetuate inequality. This literature review explores the dimensions of food production, access, and the movements aimed at addressing the injustices within the global food system. The global food system, characterized by its industrial scale, has been critiqued for its role in exacerbating inequalities, particularly in terms of land ownership and labor exploitation. Studies have shown that large-scale agricultural practices often displace smallholder farmers, leading to a concentration of land in the hands of a few and exacerbating rural poverty (Patel, 2012). Furthermore, the labor conditions within this system, especially in developing countries, are marked by low wages, poor working conditions, and a lack of labor rights, highlighting the systemic inequalities embedded in food production (McMichael, 2009). Food access and insecurity are critical issues that reflect broader social inequalities. Research has demonstrated that food insecurity is not merely a matter of food availability but is significantly influenced by socioeconomic status, race, and geography (Drewnowski & Specter, 2004). The concept of 'food deserts' has been used to describe areas with limited access to affordable and nutritious food, often in low-income and minority communities, underscoring the spatial dimensions of food inequality (Walker, Keane, & Burke, 2010). Intersectional identities further complicate the experience of food insecurity, as individuals navigate multiple layers of discrimination and disadvantage that affect their access to food (Slocum, 2007). The social meanings of food also play a crucial role in shaping experiences of inequality. Food is not only a source of sustenance but also a marker of identity, culture, and social status. The stigmatization of certain foods and dietary practices can reinforce social hierarchies and marginalize certain groups (Counihan & Van Esterik, 2012). In response to the inequalities and injustices of the global industrial food system, the food justice and food sovereignty movements have emerged as powerful forces for change. Food justice advocates for equitable access to healthy food and fair conditions for food workers, emphasizing the rights of marginalized communities (Alkon & Agyeman, 2011). Food sovereignty, on the other hand, focuses on the rights of peoples to define their own food systems, challenging the dominance of corporate agriculture and promoting sustainable, community-based food production (Wittman, Desmarais, & Wiebe, 2010). These movements highlight the potential for grassroots activism to address the systemic inequalities of the global food system. In conclusion, sociological research on food and inequality provides critical insights into the ways in which the global food system perpetuates social and economic disparities. By examining the intersections of food production, access, and social meanings, this body of work underscores the importance of addressing food inequality as a key component of broader efforts to achieve social justice. The food justice and food sovereignty movements offer promising avenues for challenging the status quo and creating more equitable and sustainable food systems.
